issue.message: Lint found one or more custom checks using its older Java API; these checks are still run in compatibility mode, but this causes duplicated parsing, and in the next version lint will no longer include this legacy mode. Make sure the following lint detectors are upgraded to the new API: timber.lint.WrongTimberUsageDetector
issue.explanation:
Lint can be extended with "custom checks": additional checks implemented by developers and libraries to for example enforce specific API usages required by a library or a company coding style guideline.
The Lint APIs are not yet stable, so these checks may either cause a performance, degradation, or stop working, or provide wrong results.
This warning flags custom lint checks that are found to be using obsolete APIs and will need to be updated to run in the current lint environment.

issue.message: Not targeting the latest versions of Android; compatibility modes apply. Consider testing and updating this version. Consult the `android.os.Build.VERSION_CODES` javadoc for details.
issue.summary: Target SDK attribute is not targeting latest version
issue.explanation:
When your application runs on a version of Android that is more recent than your `targetSdkVersion` specifies that it has been tested with, various compatibility modes kick in. This ensures that your application continues to work, but it may look out of place. For example, if the `targetSdkVersion` is less than 14, your app may get an option button in the UI.
To fix this issue, set the `targetSdkVersion` to the highest available value. Then test your app to make sure everything works correctly. You may want to consult the compatibility notes to see what changes apply to each version you are adding support for: http://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/Build.VERSION_CODES.html

issue.message: A newer version of com.google.code.gson:gson than 2.2.+ is available: 2.8.0
issue.explanation: This detector looks for usages of libraries where the version you are using is not the current stable release. Using older versions is fine, and there are cases where you deliberately want to stick with an older version. However, you may simply not be aware that a more recent version is available, and that is what this lint check helps find.

issue.message: Avoid using + in version numbers; can lead to unpredictable and unrepeatable builds (com.google.code.gson:gson:2.2.+)
issue.explanation: Using `+` in dependencies lets you automatically pick up the latest available version rather than a specific, named version. However, this is not recommended; your builds are not repeatable; you may have tested with a slightly different version than what the build server used. (Using a dynamic version as the major version number is more problematic than using it in the minor version position.)

issue.message: This `minSdkVersion` value (`14`) is not used; it is always overridden by the value specified in the Gradle build script (`14`)
issue.summary: Value overridden by Gradle build script
issue.explanation: The value of (for example) `minSdkVersion` is only used if it is not specified in the `build.gradle` build scripts. When specified in the Gradle build scripts, the manifest value is ignored and can be misleading, so should be removed to avoid ambiguity.

issue.message: This `targetSdkVersion` value (`25`) is not used; it is always overridden by the value specified in the Gradle build script (`26`)
issue.summary: Value overridden by Gradle build script
issue.explanation: The value of (for example) `minSdkVersion` is only used if it is not specified in the `build.gradle` build scripts. When specified in the Gradle build scripts, the manifest value is ignored and can be misleading, so should be removed to avoid ambiguity.

issue.message: Using `setJavaScriptEnabled` can introduce XSS vulnerabilities into your application, review carefully.
issue.explanation: Your code should not invoke `setJavaScriptEnabled` if you are not sure that your app really requires JavaScript support.

issue.message: Unnecessary; SDK_INT is always >= 14
issue.explanation:
This check flags version checks that are not necessary, because the `minSdkVersion` (or surrounding known API level) is already at least as high as the version checked for.
Similarly, it also looks for resources in `-vNN` folders, such as `values-v14` where the version qualifier is less than or equal to the `minSdkVersion`, where the contents should be merged into the best folder.

issue.message: Missing density variation folders in `src/main/res`: drawable-hdpi, drawable-mdpi, drawable-xxhdpi
issue.explanation:
Icons will look best if a custom version is provided for each of the major screen density classes (low, medium, high, extra-high, extra-extra-high). This lint check identifies folders which are missing, such as `drawable-hdpi`.
Low density is not really used much anymore, so this check ignores the ldpi density. To force lint to include it, set the environment variable `ANDROID_LINT_INCLUDE_LDPI=true`. For more information on current density usage, see http://developer.android.com/resources/dashboard/screens.html

issue.message: Custom view `ConversationButton` is missing constructor used by tools: `(Context)` or `(Context,AttributeSet)` or `(Context,AttributeSet,int)`
issue.summary: Missing View constructors for XML inflation
issue.explanation:
Some layout tools (such as the Android layout editor) need to find a constructor with one of the following signatures: * `View(Context context)` * `View(Context context, AttributeSet attrs)` * `View(Context context, AttributeSet attrs, int defStyle)`
If your custom view needs to perform initialization which does not apply when used in a layout editor, you can surround the given code with a check to see if `View#isInEditMode()` is false, since that method will return `false` at runtime but true within a user interface editor.
issue.errorLine1: public class ConversationButton extends android.widget.Button implements IConversationControl {

issue.message: Custom view ``YoutubeVideoView`` has `setOnTouchListener` called on it but does not override `performClick`
issue.explanation: If a `View` that overrides `onTouchEvent` or uses an `OnTouchListener` does not also implement `performClick` and call it when clicks are detected, the `View` may not handle accessibility actions properly. Logic handling the click actions should ideally be placed in `View#performClick` as some accessibility services invoke `performClick` when a click action should occur.

issue.message: `onTouch` should call `View#performClick` when a click is detected
issue.explanation: If a `View` that overrides `onTouchEvent` or uses an `OnTouchListener` does not also implement `performClick` and call it when clicks are detected, the `View` may not handle accessibility actions properly. Logic handling the click actions should ideally be placed in `View#performClick` as some accessibility services invoke `performClick` when a click action should occur.
issue.errorLine1: public boolean onTouch(View v, MotionEvent event) {

issue.message: Use "`Gravity.START`" instead of "`Gravity.LEFT`" to ensure correct behavior in right-to-left locales
issue.summary: Using left/right instead of start/end attributes
issue.explanation:
Using `Gravity#LEFT` and `Gravity#RIGHT` can lead to problems when a layout is rendered in locales where text flows from right to left. Use `Gravity#START` and `Gravity#END` instead. Similarly, in XML `gravity` and `layout_gravity` attributes, use `start` rather than `left`.
For XML attributes such as paddingLeft and `layout_marginLeft`, use `paddingStart` and `layout_marginStart`. **NOTE**: If your `minSdkVersion` is less than 17, you should add **both** the older left/right attributes **as well as** the new start/right attributes. On older platforms, where RTL is not supported and the start/right attributes are unknown and therefore ignored, you need the older left/right attributes. There is a separate lint check which catches that type of error.
(Note: For `Gravity#LEFT` and `Gravity#START`, you can use these constants even when targeting older platforms, because the `start` bitmask is a superset of the `left` bitmask. Therefore, you can use `gravity="start"` rather than `gravity="left|start"`.)

issue.message: Use "`Gravity.END`" instead of "`Gravity.RIGHT`" to ensure correct behavior in right-to-left locales
issue.summary: Using left/right instead of start/end attributes
issue.explanation:
Using `Gravity#LEFT` and `Gravity#RIGHT` can lead to problems when a layout is rendered in locales where text flows from right to left. Use `Gravity#START` and `Gravity#END` instead. Similarly, in XML `gravity` and `layout_gravity` attributes, use `start` rather than `left`.
For XML attributes such as paddingLeft and `layout_marginLeft`, use `paddingStart` and `layout_marginStart`. **NOTE**: If your `minSdkVersion` is less than 17, you should add **both** the older left/right attributes **as well as** the new start/right attributes. On older platforms, where RTL is not supported and the start/right attributes are unknown and therefore ignored, you need the older left/right attributes. There is a separate lint check which catches that type of error.
(Note: For `Gravity#LEFT` and `Gravity#START`, you can use these constants even when targeting older platforms, because the `start` bitmask is a superset of the `left` bitmask. Therefore, you can use `gravity="start"` rather than `gravity="left|start"`.)
